data.text: Jandd. The Ortliebs are pretty and slick looking and definitely waterproof but going down a gravelly descent picking up speed that stupid little clip that holds them down at the bottom start wobbling and makes your whole ride start shimmying you might want some beefy elastic cords stabilizing your load.

data.text: I‚Äôve been using rockbros I found on amazon. They have held up surprisingly well.
data.author: Justin Trigg

data.text: I have these too. They both had immediate cosmetic malfunctions. The bungee toggle stoppers popped off so I had to tie them together to keep the bungee toggles from coming off the ends. And the sewing on the trim where you roll down the top started coming undone on day 1. They aren't expensive and these problems don't impact the function of the panniers so they work fine, just be mindful the construction isn't the best.
data.author: Mary Williams Stuessy

data.text: they have held up surprisingly well for me. Some of more expensive gear is the stuff i usually have issues with, believe it or not.

data.text: , price. Ortlieb is best and I use nothing else but they ARE the most expensive.
data.author: Louie Garcia

data.text: There are definitely more expensive bags than Ortlieb. Also, there are plenty of used Ortlieb bags to be found on eBay. Plus, Ortlieb has all sorts of spare parts they will happily mail to you in every corner of the world. Once you have been on the road for a few weeks you will appreciate Ortlieb's superior reliability. Lastly, compared to convential travel, you save so much money when you travel by bike. So why not invest the extra few & on your most essential gear.
data.author: Thomas Arson

data.text: True initial outlay is a lot, but divided by the years mine has lasted they have more than paid for themselves especially in the wet as I carry laptops to work
data.author: Richard Cragg

data.text: , I would really question, why to spent so much money on Ortlib if you can get same or better quality for less money??

data.author: Darryl Pierce

data.text: I have had some novara shopping panniers for like 15 years that I picked up on clearance and aside from one of the springs stretching I still use them a lot. Swift Industries makes panniers as well. They are a bit on the pricey side. Thule was another brand I considered at one point. My experience is that metal mounting hardware holds up the best. Plastic hardware you have to be more cautious about quality and go with trusted brands. Just look at the bags and how they are reinforced/manufactured.
data.author: Natalie Stenger

data.text: , Novara are good. I hate that REI discontinued that line.
data.author: Louie Garcia

data.text: yes that was a poor decision! I have a 2006 Safari Novara bike.
data.author: Joseph Koziol

data.text: , EVERY kind of RIDING GLOVE I owned for a time (fingerless warm-weather or waterproof insulated cold-weather) were PERFECT Novara cycling gloves.
data.author: Louie Garcia

data.text: I have been watching a video series of a couple riding across the U.S. and the guy is riding a Novara. I had to google the brand because REI has been "Co-op" for so long now. Looking at what REI now offers, it looks like they have pulled the plug on non-electric touring bikes altogether. The only bikes listed as "touring" are e-bikes. I know they had a non-electric touring bike or two in their catalog a couple of years ago.
data.author: Justin Stephen

data.text: , yes. REI is more interested in getting ‚Äúeverybody outside,‚Äù than they are specifically catering to cyclists. I don‚Äôt fault them for trying to make a profit. I just wish they hadn‚Äôt discontinued the high-quality bicycling equipment that they once carried. ÔøºÔøº

data.text: Ortlieb panniers are certainly waterproof and durable, and they seem to be the go to panniers for most cycle tourists. However, and I expect because they are 100% waterproof, I find that my clothes can become musky in them. Also, the absence of external pockets is negative of the brand. I think though that external pockets can be added after purchase.
